results.title: Embracing the Future
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Historian and environmentalist Dr. Jonathon King points to an optimistic future, citing that humans are rational beings with the capacity to change and ensure a sustainable future. Phillip Toyne, Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, demonstrates viable ways of reversing much of the damage done to our soil. Presenter Sue Hanckel concludes that “…we owe it to ourselves and our children to embrace the future with a vision that is life-affirming and positive.”

results.title: Extinction is forever
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Under southern skies”.
This episode looks at various species that are endangered in Australia. Doctor Tony Oliver of the West Australian Department of Agriculture discusses the complex and fragile interdependence of Australia’s plant kingdom and animals.

results.title: Forest for the Trees
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Within 30 years, at the present rate of logging, all available old forests will have been felled for timber. This program takes us to Eden on the south coast of N.S.W and Pemberton in W.A in an effort to understand how we can balance our commercial need for a timber industry with our vital need to conserve and protect the environment. Presented by Ruth Hanckel.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media

results.title: Healing is believing
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Under southern skies”.
In this episode, host Sue Henckel travels to the Gulf of Carpentaria where her guide Thancoupie, an aboriginal healer, takes her on a practical excursion revealing her traditional knowledge of plants that have been used for centuries for their medicinal properties. Thancoupie collects a variety of plants and prepares them to treat ailments such as diarrhoea, colds and tropical ulcers. She also reveals methods used by her ancestors to control their birth-rate discussing the consequences of large families in nomadic tribes.

results.title: Custodians of the bush
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Sue Henckel travels to far north Queensland to meet Thancoupie, an Aboriginal healer, who explains the ancient tradition of holistic medicine that nurtures, heals and protects. Thancoupie provides an education on the qualities and properties of Australian native flora, showing that it is the hunter gatherers who have provided the rich source of essential substances used in modern medicines.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media

results.title: Our Fragile Wilderness
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Under southern skies”.
The south-west corner of Western Australia has a relatively undisturbed ecosystem where 85% of the plants grow nowhere else in Australia. Grant Wardell-Johnson, a committed ecologist, guides series presenter, Susie Hanckel, through this region of giant Karri and Jarrah forests and swamps, revealing how the the impact of man’s encroachment on this ecosystem can be gauged by studying certain unique species of frogs in the area.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media

results.title: Distinctively Australian
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Series presenter, Dr Susie Hanckel, leaves her city environment to examine what makes the ecosystems in our 400million year old country distinctively Australian. She looks at the adaptation of plants to the extremes of Australian climatic conditions - from the arid deserts and the snow covered eucalypts of the Australian Alps to the rainforests of North Queensland. This episode features distinguished scientist and specialist on Australia’s High Country, Alec Costain.

results.title: Living on a thin thread
results.creator_credit: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Under southern skies”.
Paleobotanist Mary White explains the origins of the unique plant life of Australia, when it was part of the huge land mass, Gondwana, and the resulting evolution of plant life as it adapted to warmer conditions. Mary White challenged presenter Sue Hanckel to consider the earth as a complex balanced system, like the human body, with man, the virus, that threatens Earth’s very existence. Sue discovers a reaffirmation of Carl Jung’s observation that the future of our world hangs on a delicate thread.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Edols, Mark Falzon and Central Coast Media

results.title: Flipping the world
results.creator_credit: Moira Simpson, George Johnson, Gillian Darling Kovanic and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Inspired by the documentary “Through a blue lens” (311463) which also features the work of the Odd Squad - Vancouver police officers who, since 1998, have been filming people addicted to drugs. “Flipping the World” is a brutally honest look at the world of youth and drug addiction, told by those who have been there. A culturally diverse group of seven high school students meets with members of the Odd Squad. The students talk to the police, then meet young people who are in recovery, and others still struggling with drug addiction. In the process, their views on drugs and the people who use them undergo important shifts. The students become more understanding and empathetic, and they reveal their own drug experiences. An important discussion-starter, “Flipping the World” provides a wealth of teaching material for educators and others who work with young people.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Moira Simpson, George Johnson, Gillian Darling Kovanic and National Film Board of Canada
results.description: Inspired by the documentary “Through a blue lens” (311463) which also features the work of the Odd Squad - Vancouver police officers who, since 1998, have been filming people addicted to drugs. “Flipping the World” is a brutally honest look at the world of youth and drug addiction, told by those who have been there. A culturally diverse group of seven high school students meets with members of the Odd Squad. The students talk to the police, then meet young people who are in recovery, and others still struggling with drug addiction. In the process, their views on drugs and the people who use them undergo important shifts. The students become more understanding and empathetic, and they reveal their own drug experiences. An important discussion-starter, “Flipping the World” provides a wealth of teaching material for educators and others who work with young people.

results.title: Flip book [interactive]
results.brief_description:
An interactive allowing visitors to make their own flip books that can be saved to their Lens. Visitors can also purchase printed versions of their flip books in the ACMI Shop.

Visitors stand in front of flipbook maker and select ‘record’, they are then advised to ‘get ready’.

When recording, a count down timer will advise of how long visitors have left.

Visitors can then save their flipbook to their lens and then proceed to the ACMI shop for printing.

This interactive was re-booted from ACMI’s previous exhibition “Screen Worlds” because it was a crowd favourite. The design of the interactive and flipbook has been updated.
